chunks.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation

That the bodies of living creatures are compounded from hot and cold, dry and moist, and that the proportion in the mixture is not equal for all, has been adequately demonstrated by the men of old, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. We too have stated what is reasonable concerning these matters in another work, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, which is the next step after that work, I shall proceed in this present writing to discover all the differences of mixtures [or temperaments], both how many they are and of what kind, dividing them by species and genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.
chunks.openai_translation: That, then, the bodies of animals are compounded from the hot and the cold, the dry and the moist, and that the share of each in the mixture is not the same in all, has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients—the best among both philosophers and physicians. And we too have presented the plausible considerations on these matters in another treatise [γράμμα = treatise], in which we examined the elements [στοιχεῖα = elements] according to Hippocrates. Now, as a sequel to that, I shall in this treatise go through all the differences of the temperaments [κράσεις = mixtures/temperaments]—how many they are and of what sort—dividing them by species and by genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms [ὀνόματα = technical terms].
chunks.gemini_translation: That the bodies of animals are compounded, then, from the hot and the cold, and the dry and the wet, and that the proportion of these is not equal for all in their mixture [κράσις: literally "mixture" or "blending"; the technical term for the temperament or constitution of the body], has been sufficiently demonstrated by men of old, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. The appropriate arguments concerning these matters have also been stated by us in another treatise, in which we examined the elements [στοιχεῖον: "element" or "principle"; in this context, the fundamental qualities] according to Hippocrates. But now, as the next topic in sequence, in this present treatise I shall go through and set out all the differences among the mixtures—how many and of what sort they are—dividing them according to species and genera, making my beginning from an explanation of the terms.

chunks.content: ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and wet, they assert that one must understand [this to refer to] things that are such in the extreme degree, that is, the elements themselves—air, and fire, and water, and earth. But whenever [they speak of] an animal, or a plant, or [something] hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, [one must] no longer [understand it] in the same way.
chunks.openai_translation: For whenever they say that bodies are mixed from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the moist [the four elemental qualities], they say one must understand these in their most extreme form—that is, as their elements: air, fire, water, and earth; but whenever [they speak of] a living being, or a plant, or [call something] hot, or cold, or dry, or moist, it is not in the same way.
chunks.gemini_translation:
For when they say that bodies are blended [κεκρᾶσθαι] from the hot and the cold and the dry and the wet, they maintain that one must understand this to mean these qualities in their extreme form, that is, the elements [στοιχεῖα] themselves—air, and fire, and water, and earth; but when [they speak of] an animal, or a plant, or of something as hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is no longer in the same way.

**Notes:**
[κεκρᾶσθαι]: "to be blended" or "compounded." This refers to the concept of *krasis* (κρᾶσις), the specific temperament or mixture of the fundamental qualities that constitutes a body.
[στοιχείων]: "elements." The fundamental, simple bodies (in this context, earth, water, air, and fire) from which all other, more complex bodies are composed.

chunks.content: οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For no living creature can be extremely hot in its nature, like fire, nor extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither can it be cold or dry in the extreme. Rather, the designations arise from what predominates in the mixture [krasis], we calling "moist" that in which there is a greater portion of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is dryness; and in the same way also "hot" that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.openai_translation: For no living thing can exist as utterly hot, like fire, nor as at the extreme moist, like water; and likewise neither as to the utmost cold nor dry. Rather, our appellations are derived from what predominates in the mixture [krasis]: we call that moist in which there is a larger share of moisture, and dry that in which there is [a larger share of] dryness; and likewise hot, that in which the hot predominates over the cold, and cold, that in which the cold predominates over the hot. Such, then, is the usage of the terms.
chunks.gemini_translation: For no living being can exist that is extremely hot, like fire, nor extremely wet, like water; and in the same way, it cannot be extremely cold or dry. But rather, the designations arise from what is predominant in the mixture [krasis]: we call a thing wet in which there is a greater portion of wetness, and dry in which there is [a greater portion] of dryness; and so too, hot in which the hot predominates over the cold, and cold in which the cold [predominates over] the hot. Such, then, is the use of these names.

chunks.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

**Text 2:**

Now it would be time to speak also about the mixtures [temperaments] themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and hot mixture [temperament], another distinct from this which is moist and cold, and a third in addition to these which is dry and cold, and yet another which is both dry and hot.

[Note: κρᾶσις (krasis) refers to the mixture or blending of the fundamental qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) that were believed to constitute bodily temperaments in ancient Greek medical theory, particularly in Galenic medicine.]
chunks.openai_translation: Now would be the time to speak also about their mixtures: the most prevalent opinion among the most eminent physicians and philosophers is that there is a moist and warm mixture [krâsis: qualitative “mixture” or temperament], a second, the moist and cold, and, in addition to these, a third, the dry and cold, and a fourth, the dry and at the same time warm.
chunks.gemini_translation:
It would now be time to speak of the temperaments [kraseis] themselves. The most widespread opinion, then, of the most eminent physicians and philosophers, is that there is a moist and hot temperament, which is different from the moist and cold; and a third in addition to these, the dry and cold, which is different from the dry and also hot.

[kraseis: singular *krasis*. Literally 'mixture' or 'blending'; the technical term for the physiological 'temperament' or 'constitution' determined by the balance of the four humors.]

chunks.content: ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Some of them say that there exists a certain mixture that is both moist and cold at the same time, and another that is hot and dry at the same time; however, neither a mixture that is both moist and hot at the same time, nor one that is both cold and dry at the same time—for it is not possible either for moisture to combine with predominant heat, or for dryness to combine with coldness.
chunks.openai_translation: Some of them say that there exists a certain mixture [krâsis: blending of primary qualities] that is moist and at the same time cold, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, however, one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry—for it is not possible for moisture to come together with predominating heat, nor for dryness with cold.
chunks.gemini_translation: Some of them say that one kind of temperament [κρᾶσις: mixture, constitution] exists that is at once moist and cold, and another that is at once hot and dry; but not, however, one that is at once moist and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For it is not possible for moisture to combine with a prevailing heat, nor for dryness to combine with coldness.

chunks.content: δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.3:

For moisture is consumed by the hot when it prevails, and thus the body becomes hot and dry at the same time; but [the moisture] remains undigested and unconcocted in those bodies in which the hot is weak, so that it is necessary that, when heat predominates, dryness follows, and when cold has the advantage, moisture follows. These people, then, have persuaded themselves according to these arguments that all the differences of mixtures [temperaments] are two.

---

**Brief notes:**
- [mixtures/temperaments]: κράσεων refers to the blending or mixture of qualities that determine bodily constitution in ancient medical theory
- [unconcocted]: ἀκατέργαστον refers to material that has not been properly processed or worked upon by natural heat
chunks.gemini_translation: For, on the one hand, moisture is consumed by the prevailing heat, and in this way the body becomes both hot and dry; on the other hand, in those bodies in which the heat is weak, [substance] remains both undigested [apepton] and unprocessed, so that it is necessary, when heat prevails, for dryness to follow, and when cold is predominant, for moisture to accompany it. These men, therefore, on these grounds, have persuaded themselves that all the varieties of temperaments [kraseis] are two.
chunks.openai_translation: For when heat is in control, the moisture is consumed, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry, yet remains undigested and unprocessed [pepsis: “concoction”] in those bodies in which the heat is diseased; so that it is necessary that, when heat prevails, dryness follows, and when cold has the advantage, moisture follows. On such grounds, then, they have persuaded themselves that all the differences of mixtures [krasis: blending/temperament] are two in number.

chunks.content: ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν
chunks.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

Those who believe there are four [elements], however, oppose them in two ways: some immediately do not concede the first premise, on the grounds that it is not necessary for moisture to be evaporated when heat prevails; but others concede this point, yet dispute it in another manner. Now the first group say that the function of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and in turn the function of the dry is to dry, just as that of the moist is to moisten.
chunks.openai_translation: But those who think there are four [primary qualities] oppose them in two ways. Some do not grant the first axiom [basic premise] straightaway, on the grounds that it is necessary that moisture be dried out by the predominance of the hot. Others concede this, but dispute in another way: among these, the first maintain that it is the function [ergon] of the hot to heat, just as it is the function of the cold to cool, and again that it is the function of the dry to dry, as likewise of the wet to moisten.
chunks.gemini_translation: But those who believe there are four [qualities] are contradicted in two ways: some, on the one hand, do not concede the first axiom from the outset—that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by the dominant heat; others, on the other hand, concede this, but dispute the matter differently. The first group, then, says that the function [ἔργον] of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and in turn that of the dry is to dry, just as that of the wet is to moisten.

chunks.content: καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

And because of this, those bodies which are hot and dry in nature, such as fire, insofar as they are hot, heat, and insofar as they are dry, dry; but those which are moist and hot, such as hot water, are naturally disposed always to moisten and to heat, each quality in both cases having one inseparable function.
chunks.gemini_translation: And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature [φύσις] both hot and dry, such as fire, heat insofar as they are hot, and dry insofar as they are dry; whereas those that are moist and hot, such as hot water, are always by their nature disposed to moisten and to heat, since in this case too each quality [ποιότης] has its one inseparable function [ἔργον].
chunks.openai_translation: And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature both hot and dry, like fire, inasmuch as they are hot they heat, and inasmuch as they are dry they dry; whereas those that are moist and hot, like warm water, are naturally always disposed to moisten and to heat, since here too each quality [i.e., hot, dry, moist as intrinsic properties] has its single, inseparable function.

chunks.content: οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.6:

They do not agree, therefore, that if something is heating, it immediately also dries; but rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, just as baths of fresh water do; but if, just as it is hot, it is also dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this not from the heat but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they remind us of those who have spent excessive time in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become withered, having their whole body both dry and parched, and suffering unbearably from thirst.
chunks.gemini_translation: Therefore, they do not concede that if something is heating, it also immediately dries. Rather, if moisture were present with the heat, it heats and at the same time moistens, like baths of fresh waters [i.e., not salt water]; but if, just as it is hot, it were also dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this effect not from the heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it. And at this point they bring to mind the case of those who have spent too much time in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become dried out, having their whole body both dry and parched, and being unbearably thirsty.
chunks.openai_translation: Accordingly they do not concede that, if something is heating, it immediately also dries; rather, if moisture is present along with the heat, it both heats and moistens, as do the baths of fresh waters [“sweet” = non‑saline]. But if, just as it is hot, it is also dry, like fire, it will not only heat but also dry at once—deriving this [i.e., the drying] not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it. And here they call to mind people who have lingered too long in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become parched, their whole body being dry and rough, and suffering thirst intolerably.

chunks.content: ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that there is a ready and very easy cure for them, not only if they should drink [the waters], but also if they should bathe in warm and sweet waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it be accompanied by coldness or by heat, is able to perform its own function—namely, to moisten things that come near it. And according to the same reasoning, they say that dryness also always dries out [things].
chunks.openai_translation: For they say that a cure is for them ready at hand and the easiest, not only by drinking but even by bathing in warm and “sweet” water [i.e., fresh, non-saline], since moisture, whether accompanied by cold or by heat, is able to do its own proper work—for it moistens what comes near; and on the same reasoning they say that dryness always dries.
chunks.gemini_translation: For they say that a ready and very easy cure is available to them, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in hot and fresh [lit. sweet] waters, on the principle that moisture is able to perform its own function—whether it be with coldness or with hotness—for its function is to moisten whatever is near. And by the same reasoning, they say that dryness, too, always dries.

chunks.content: τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει
chunks.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

The north wind, at any rate, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything, and this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries the newly watered threshing floor"

---

**Notes:**
[βοῤῥᾶν/Βορέας - the north wind, personified in Greek mythology]
[ἀλωή - threshing floor, a flat area for processing grain]
chunks.gemini_translation: The north wind [Boreas], at any rate, being by nature a dry and cold wind, dries and cools all things, and this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind swiftly dries a newly-watered threshing-floor [ἀλωήν]..."
chunks.openai_translation: Accordingly, the North Wind, being a dry and cold wind, dries everything and cools; and this is what is said by Homer: “As when the autumnal North Wind [Boreas] quickly dries a newly watered threshing-floor.”

chunks.content: Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ
chunks.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

In the same manner, poppy juice and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time, so that it is not necessary that if something is cold, it is immediately also moist, nor if something is hot, it is immediately also dry. Therefore, neither is it necessary that a hot mixture [krasis] be also dry, but it is possible sometimes for the hot to predominate over the cold in the mixture of the living being, while the moist predominates over the dry.
chunks.openai_translation: In the same way, the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and cool at once, so that it is not necessary that, if something is cold, it immediately is also moist, nor that, if something is hot, it immediately is also dry. Therefore a warm mixture [krasis, temperament] is not necessarily also dry; rather, it can at times happen that, in the mixture of a living creature, the hot element prevails over the cold, while the moist prevails over the dry.
chunks.gemini_translation: And in the same way, the juice of the poppy [opium] and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time, so that it is not necessary either for something cold to be immediately also moist, or for something hot to be immediately also dry. Consequently, a hot temperament [krasis] is not necessarily also dry, but it is possible for the hot sometimes to predominate over the cold in the temperament of a living being, while the moist predominates over the dry.

chunks.content: καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"For indeed, both coming-to-be, and alteration, and change occur from opposites into opposites. For who then, saying that the white thing has been altered and has changed—for it has become hot—would not be ridiculous?"

[Note: The text appears to have a syntactical irregularity. A more natural rendering accounting for the apparent rhetorical question structure might be: "For who then, saying that the white thing has been altered and has changed because it has become hot, would not be ridiculous?"]
chunks.gemini_translation: For indeed, coming-to-be [genesis], and alteration [alloiosis], and change [metabole] occur from opposites into opposites. For what person, then, who said that the white was both altered and changed (for it became hot), would not be ridiculous?
chunks.openai_translation: For indeed generation [coming-to-be], alteration [qualitative change], and change from contraries into contraries [opposed qualities] do occur; for who, then, in saying that what is white was altered and changed—for it became hot—would not be laughable?

chunks.content: ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For the argument seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but rather the change in respect to color; for white changes into black, just as black also changes into white, and hot in turn changes into cold, just as cold also changes into hot; and in the same way, wet changes into dry, and dry in turn changes into wet.
chunks.openai_translation: For the argument inquires not into the opposition [of contraries] with respect to cold and hot, but into the change with respect to color; for white changes into black, just as black into white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold into the hot; and so too the moist into the dry, and in turn the dry into the moist.
chunks.gemini_translation: For the argument [or account] seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change of color; for the white changes into the black, just as the black also changes into the white, and the hot in turn into the cold, just as the cold also into the hot; so too the wet changes into the dry, and the dry in turn into the wet.

chunks.content: εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.12:

For if someone were to claim that the body has been altered by the fact that what was previously moist now is white, or by the fact that what was previously dry now appears black, he would not seem to be of sound mind; but if he were to say that what was previously moist has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that it has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be thinking sensibly and speaking plausibly.
chunks.gemini_translation: For if someone asserts that the body has been altered in that what was previously moist is now white, or that what was previously dry now appears black, he would not seem to be of sound mind; but if he were to say that what was previously moist has now become dry, or that what was previously black is now white, or has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem to be of sound mind, and to be saying what is reasonable.
chunks.openai_translation: For if someone claims that the body has undergone alteration [alloiōsis] on the grounds that what was formerly moist is now white, or that what was formerly dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind; but if he should say that what was formerly moist has now become dry, or that what previously was black is now white, or that from being hot it has become cold, or from being cold hot [primary qualities], such a person would seem to be sensible and to speak what is plausible.

chunks.content: τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον
chunks.claude_translation:
# Translation of Text 2.13:

For that which changes, insofar as it changes, must in that respect shift toward the opposite. At any rate, this person became or becomes musical, we say, from being non-musical obviously, and literate from being non-literate, and skilled in rhetoric from being non-skilled in rhetoric. But to say that something becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or from some other thing of a different kind [genus] is absurd.
chunks.gemini_translation: For that which undergoes change must, in the respect that it changes, pass over to its contrary [to enantion]. For instance, we say that this man became, or is becoming, a musician, clearly from being a non-musician, and a grammarian from a non-grammarian, and a rhetorician from a non-rhetorician; but to say that a grammarian comes to be from a musician, or a musician from a grammarian, or that anything comes to be from something else of a different kind [heterogenēs], is absurd.
chunks.openai_translation: For that which is undergoing change, in the respect in which it changes, must in that respect pass over to the contrary [opposite]. At any rate, we say that this man has become or is becoming musical, plainly from being not-musical, and a grammarian from being not a grammarian, and a rhetorician from being not a rhetorician; but to say that something becomes a grammarian from being musical, or musical from being a grammarian, or from some other of the heterogeneous [of a different kind/genus], is absurd.

chunks.content: ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"For it is possible that someone who was formerly a grammarian has now become a musician, having acquired music in addition to grammar, without having lost grammar. And indeed, if he has acquired something in addition while the former thing remains, it is surely clear to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to that which remains."
chunks.gemini_translation: For it is possible for the one who was formerly a grammarian to have now become musical, by acquiring music in addition to grammar, without having lost his grammar. And indeed, if he acquired something while the former thing remained, it is surely clear to everyone that he was not altered [i.e., changed in quality] in respect of that which remained.
chunks.openai_translation: For it is possible that the one who was formerly a grammarian has now become a musician, having acquired the art of music in addition to the art of grammar [i.e., technical disciplines], not having cast grammar away; and indeed, if he has acquired something while the former remains, it is plain to everyone that he has not been altered with respect to what remains.

chunks.content: ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"So then, he did not become musical from being grammatical; for indeed even now he is still grammatical. Rather, he became musical from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, having already become musical. At any rate, since all changes occur from opposites and out of opposites into opposites, clearly also the moist, if it ever changes, insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and that which dries it will be called dry."
chunks.gemini_translation: Therefore, he did not become musical *from* being a grammarian; for in fact, he is still a grammarian even now. Rather, he became musical from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become musical. Since, at any rate, all changes [μεταβολαί] are brought about by, and proceed from, contraries [ἐναντίων] into their contraries, it is clear that the wet, too, if it ever changes—insofar as it is wet—will itself be dried, and the agent that dries it will be called dry.
chunks.openai_translation: So he did not become musical from being literate [grammatikos]; for even now he is still literate; rather, he became musical from being unmusical. For it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, once he has already become musical; at any rate, all changes [metabolai] come about both through contraries and from contraries into contraries [opposites]. Clearly, too, the wet thing, if it ever changes, insofar as it is wet, will itself be dried, and the thing that dries it will be called dry.

chunks.content: μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"Therefore, they say, let them not claim that it is impossible for a mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time. For it is impossible for the same thing to be both hot and cold at the same time, or both moist and dry at the same time; for it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at the same time, and both cold and dry at the same time, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples given a little earlier show."
chunks.gemini_translation: Therefore, let them not say, as they say, that a temperament [κρᾶσις] that is at once hot and moist cannot come into being. For the same thing cannot be simultaneously hot and cold, or simultaneously moist and dry, since it is not possible for contrary qualities to coexist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a little before.
chunks.openai_translation: Then let them not say—so they maintain—that a mixture [krasis: blending/temperament] that is at once hot and moist cannot come to be; for it is not possible for the same thing to be at once hot and cold, or at once moist and dry; for contrary qualities cannot co-exist with one another in one and the same body. But it is possible for something to be at once moist and hot, and at once cold and dry, as both the argument has demonstrated and the examples mentioned a little earlier.

chunks.content: τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Such, then, is the argument of the first group; but the argument of the second group says that there is nothing absurd, given that the hot is the most active of the four [elements/qualities], in that it acts not only upon the cold, but also upon the moist, in there being a mixture [krasis] that is moist and hot, whenever a quantity of both moisture and heat comes together at the same time right from the first generation of the animal.
chunks.openai_translation: Such, then, is the account of the former; but the account of the latter says there is nothing out of place in this, given that heat, being the most active of the four [qualities], acts not only upon the cold but also upon the moist; that there is a moist and warm mixture [krasis] whenever, at one and the same time, an abundance of moisture and of heat comes together in the same subject, immediately at the first coming-to-be of the animal.
chunks.gemini_translation: Such, then, is the argument of the former group; the latter group, however, asserts that it is nothing absurd for a wet and hot mixture [krasis] to exist whenever an abundance of both wetness and hotness comes together at the same time, right at the first generation of the living being, on the premise that the hot is the most active of the four [qualities], acting not only upon the cold but also upon the wet.

chunks.content: ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

But their argument demonstrates not that it could never happen that in one and the same body the moist should be greater than the dry, and the hot than the cold, but rather that such a condition could not persist forever. For the moisture, being constantly evaporated by the heat over time, will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. And then again this very thing, the hot and dry, as time advances will become dry and cold. For when the heat has consumed all its moisture, from that point on, they say, it too begins to waste away, no longer having an abundance of nourishment from which it was kindled.
chunks.gemini_translation: But their argument demonstrates not that it could never happen in one and the same body that the moist is greater than the dry and the hot greater than the cold, but that such a state could not persist forever; for the moist, being continually dried out by the hot, will in time render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. Then again, this very thing, the hot and dry, will after a long time become dry and cold. For when the hot has consumed all its moisture [Greek: *ikmas*], it too—so they say—then begins to waste away, no longer being well supplied with the nourishment from which it was kindled.
chunks.openai_translation: But their argument does not show that it could never come about that, in one and the same body, the moist exceeds the dry and the hot the cold; rather, that such a condition would not endure for all time. For since the moist is continually being dried out by the hot, in the course of time it will render the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but hot and dry. And this very state again, the hot and dry, as time goes on will become dry and cold; for when the hot has consumed [lit. grazed off] all its moisture [ἰκμάς: natural sap/juice], from that point, they say, it too begins to be quenched, no longer well supplied with the nourishment from which it had been kindled.

chunks.content: θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

Therefore they consider it nothing remarkable, both that at the beginning, immediately at the first generation of the animal, either the moist may converge into the same [mixture] in greater proportion than the dry, or the hot than the cold, and that it is also possible as time progresses for a mixture that was previously hot and moist to become in turn hot and dry, just as also in turn again for one that is dry and hot, when the hot is extinguished, to become cold and dry.
chunks.gemini_translation: Therefore, they believe it is nothing surprising that, on the one hand, right at the beginning in the initial generation of the living creature, either the wet should combine in greater quantity than the dry, or the hot than the cold; and that it is also possible, on the other hand, as time goes on, for the temperament [krasis] that was for a time hot and wet to become in turn hot and dry, just as, indeed, the hot and dry temperament, as its heat is extinguished, can once again be rendered cold and dry.
chunks.openai_translation: Accordingly they suppose there is nothing surprising: on the one hand, that at the outset, immediately at the animal’s first coming-to-be, either moisture should prevail over dryness or heat over cold; on the other hand, that as time goes on it is possible for the mixture [krasis, blend] that was previously hot and moist to become again hot and dry—just as indeed, in turn, the hot-and-dry, as the heat is quenched, may come to be cold and dry.

chunks.content: ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"That it is possible, then, for one mixture to be both hot and moist at the same time, and for another mixture different from this one to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations; but that it is impossible for there to exist more than four varieties of mixtures, they attempt to teach from the following arguments."
chunks.openai_translation: That, then, it is possible for something to be at once hot and moist, and for another mixture [krâsis: mixture/temperament], different from this one, to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these considerations; but that it is impossible for there to exist more than four differences of mixtures, they attempt to show from the following.
chunks.gemini_translation:
That it is possible, then, for a certain temperament [krasis] to be at once hot and wet, and for another to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these preceding points; but that it is impossible for more than four varieties of temperaments to exist, they attempt to teach from the following.

[krasis]: A mixture or blending; in medical and philosophical contexts, it refers to the "temperament" or "constitution" of a body, resulting from the mixture of fundamental qualities.

chunks.content: ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

For they say that there being four underlying qualities, which have the power both to act upon and be acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise: one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the moist. And for this reason all the combinations that are completed are four in number. For when the four are interwoven with one another, six couplings arise, but two of these turn out to be impossible.
chunks.openai_translation: For, they say, since four qualities [i.e., primary qualities] are posited, capable of acting upon and being acted upon by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—two oppositions arise: the one in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other in which the dry is opposed to the wet; and for this reason all the pairings [syzygies: combinations of two qualities] amount to four. For six couplings of the four, as they are interwoven with one another, do come to be, but two of these are impossible.
chunks.gemini_translation: For they say that, since there are four underlying qualities—heat and cold, and dryness and wetness—which possess the capacity to act and be acted upon in relation to one another, two oppositions arise: the one, in which the hot is opposed to the cold, and the other, in which the dry is opposed to the wet. And for this reason, four total pairings [συζυγίας] are formed; for while six couplings [συζεύξεις] would arise from the four being interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible.

chunks.content: οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας
chunks.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

For a body cannot be both moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time. It follows, then, that there are four combinations of mixtures [or temperaments]: two moist ones and two dry ones, distinguished by heat and coldness.
chunks.openai_translation: For a body can neither come to be moist and dry at the same time, nor cold and hot at the same time; accordingly, it remains that there are four pairings of mixtures [kraseis: mixture/temperament], two moist and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold.
chunks.gemini_translation: For a body cannot become at once wet and dry, nor at once cold and hot. It remains, therefore, that there are four pairings of temperaments [kraseis]: two wet and two dry, distinguished by heat and cold.

chunks.content: ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
chunks.claude_translation:
Here is the translation:

"These, then, are the things which the most accomplished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said; but what I believe they have omitted, it is now time to discuss."
chunks.openai_translation: So then, the things which the most accomplished of the physicians and philosophers before us have said—these are they; but as for what I think they have omitted, it is now time to speak.
chunks.gemini_translation: These, then, are the things which the most accomplished of the physicians and philosophers before our time have stated; but as for what I believe they have omitted, it is now the opportune moment [kairos] to speak.
